The passage just after Mrs Miller discovered the body was particularly well done - â€˜Their mounting hubbub mingled with Bettyâ€™s screams and the pounding of her own frantic heartâ€˜ really captures that horrible feeling of everything falling apart and noises mingling into an incomprehensible chaos. Only criticism from me is the ending. It just felt like it didnâ€™t need to be there, and the dialogue felt a bit cliche. Maybe it should have ended with the frantic heart? I just didnâ€™t feel that it added much (except the necessary inclusion of pyjamas but given the plot an earlier appearance could have been made)

Oh and this feels like a Jen to me, gotta a Hobbsy undertone to it :-)

The mood was conjured up really well here. Love the bleakness of the seaside setting and the contrasts between present day life and how Ken remembered it. I also like that the stuff from the past isn't all rose tinted and nostalgic.

comments.message:
Nice, non-literal take on the zombie theme.

The sleep deprived life of the parents felt well realised, that despair and longing for nothing more than a good night's sleep (this piece is a pretty good contraceptive).

My first thought on that last line was that it was jarring, added in for the sake of being a shocking ending. But on reflection I think it works - it highlights Simon's hazed out state, that sleep has deprived him of self awareness.

You could tweak it ever so slightly - instead of him thinking about Autumn, have him revel in the crispness of the new day, have him perk up that with the sounds of the birds singing, and then *bang*, dustbin lorry!

comments.message:
Yes, the atmosphere is a winner for me in this piece - and not in a compliment the lighting in Joey play kind of way. Nice touches, like the white bald head dipping in and out of the light, or the smoke uncoiling.

There are a couple of places where the formatting lets it down - it almost needs a new line here and there to slow it down in a couple of places e.g. the bits when the mysterious man is talking and then switching into action.

Is the formatting how you wrote it? Have I introduced changes through the publishing process?
